questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Advisory Circular AC101-1?

options.text: To establish mandatory regulations that operators must follow
options.feedback: AC101-1 is not mandatory. It is guidance document that represents the CAA's official recommendations for compliant operations, not binding regulations.

options.text: To provide practical guidance for RPAS operators under 25kg during the regulatory transition
options.feedback: Correct! AC101-1 is specifically designed to provide practical, CAA-endorsed guidance for operators transitioning to the December 2025 framework, focusing on compliance pathways and best practices.

options.text: To replace Part 101 and Part 102 regulatory requirements
options.feedback: AC101-1 does not replace regulatory requirements. It provides guidance on how to interpret and apply existing regulatory requirements in practical operational contexts.

options.text: To outline penalties for operators who do not comply with new rules
options.feedback: AC101-1 is a guidance document focused on helping operators comply. Enforcement penalties are covered in the Civil Aviation Rules themselves, not in advisory circulars.

questions.question: What is the critical deadline for commercial operators to submit updated Part 102 certification applications?

options.feedback: 31 December 2025 marks the end of Phase 1 (Foundation), not the application deadline. Commercial operators have longer to prepare their applications.
28 February 2026 marks the end of Phase 1 and beginning of Phase 2, but the critical application deadline is later in Phase 2.
Correct! 30 April 2026 is the critical deadline for commercial operators to submit updated Part 102 certification applications during Phase 2. Missing this deadline could delay authorization.
While 30 June 2026 is near the end of Phase 2, the actual application deadline is 30 April 2026, providing time for CAA processing before Phase 3 full compliance begins.

questions.question: During Phase 1 (Foundation), what is the CAA's primary approach to enforcement?

options.text: Strict penalties for any non-compliance, regardless of circumstances
options.feedback: Phase 1 takes a supportive, educational approach. The CAA focuses on helping operators understand and prepare for compliance rather than applying penalties.

options.text: Education and support, with no enforcement action for good-faith compliance efforts
options.feedback: Correct! During Phase 1, the CAA prioritizes education and stakeholder support. Operators making good-faith efforts to understand and implement changes are not subject to enforcement action.

options.text: Selective enforcement only against large commercial operators
options.feedback: Enforcement approach during Phase 1 applies across all operator categories. Phase 1 is fundamentally different—it's the education phase, not an enforcement phase for any category.

options.text: No oversight at all—operators can do whatever they want during Phase 1
options.feedback: While Phase 1 is educational rather than enforcement-focused, compliance expectations still apply. The difference is the CAA's approach emphasizes support and understanding.

questions.question: When the CAA conducts a compliance audit, what is the most important thing you can show to demonstrate your compliance commitment?

options.text: Expensive safety equipment and modern aircraft
options.feedback: While good equipment is helpful, expensive hardware doesn't prove compliance. Auditors look for organized systems and documented practices, not equipment cost.

options.text: Clear written procedures, maintenance records, flight logs, and training documentation
options.feedback: Correct! During audits, comprehensive documentation—procedures, records, training records—demonstrates that you take compliance seriously and can show ongoing compliance capability and practices.

options.text: Verbal explanations of why you think your operations are safe
options.feedback: While being able to explain your approach is helpful, auditors require documented evidence. Verbal explanations alone cannot demonstrate systematic compliance practices.

options.text: Insurance documents showing your liability coverage
options.feedback: Insurance documents are important but don't demonstrate compliance with regulatory requirements. Auditors are looking for evidence of your compliance systems and practices.
